subject: Science
note: Content vehicles for KS2 Science. Seeded from v4 teacher feedback (Kapoor). Each vehicle is a practical investigation or enquiry linked to specific concepts.

vehicles.name: Friction Investigation
vehicles.description: Fair test investigation into how surface type affects friction. Pupils measure distance a toy car travels on different surfaces.
vehicles.variables_independent: surface type (carpet, wood, sandpaper, tile, fabric)
equipment: surface samples (carpet, wood, sandpaper, tile, fabric)
vehicles.recording_format: table of results -> bar chart -> written conclusion
vehicles.safety_notes: Low risk. Ensure ramp is stable and surfaces are secured flat.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Rougher surfaces produce more friction, so the car travels a shorter distance. Smooth surfaces produce less friction.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils identify and control variables to make the test fair? Can they measure accurately and record in a table? Can they explain their results using the concept of friction as a contact force?
success_criteria: Identify the independent, dependent, and controlled variables
Measure distance travelled accurately using standard units
Record results in a table and present as a bar chart
Explain results using the concept of friction

vehicles.name: Plant Growth Enquiry
vehicles.description: Fair test investigating what plants need to grow — varying one condition (light, water, soil, temperature) while controlling others.
vehicles.variables_independent: amount of light (dark cupboard, partial shade, full sunlight)
vehicles.recording_format: weekly measurement table -> line graph -> conclusion
vehicles.safety_notes: Wash hands after handling soil. No allergenic plants.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Plants in full sunlight grow tallest. Plants in the dark grow tall and spindly (etiolated) but pale. Plants need light for healthy growth.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils set up a fair test with only one variable changed? Can they take repeat measurements over time and spot patterns? Can they explain WHY light is important for plant growth (linking to photosynthesis at an age-appropriate level)?
success_criteria: Set up a fair test changing only one variable
Take accurate measurements weekly and record in a table
Present results as a line graph showing change over time
Explain why plants need light for healthy growth

vehicles.name: Rocks and Fossils
vehicles.description: Observation and classification enquiry — pupils examine, group, and compare rocks based on observable properties, then explore fossil formation and soil composition.
equipment: rock samples (granite, chalk, sandstone, slate, marble)
vehicles.recording_format: classification table with observable properties -> Venn diagram -> labelled diagrams of fossil formation
vehicles.safety_notes: Supervise scratch tests. Vinegar is mild acid — avoid eyes. Wash hands after handling rocks.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Pupils classify rocks by hardness, appearance, and reaction to acid. They understand that fossils form in sedimentary rock and that soil contains rock fragments plus organic material.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils group rocks using observable properties (hardness, grain, permeability)? Can they explain the three main rock types? Can they describe how fossils form in sedimentary rock? Can they explain what soil is made of?
success_criteria: Group rocks by at least 3 observable properties
Name the three main rock types with an example of each
Describe the process of fossil formation in sequence
Explain that soil is made from rock fragments and organic material

vehicles.name: Sound Investigation
vehicles.description: Pattern-seeking enquiry into how sounds are made and how pitch and volume can be changed. Pupils explore vibrations using tuning forks, rulers, and elastic bands.
vehicles.variables_independent: length of vibrating object (ruler overhang, elastic band tension)
vehicles.recording_format: observations table -> pattern statement -> diagram of vibration
vehicles.safety_notes: Keep volume levels reasonable. Tuning forks can be sharp — demonstrate correct use.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Sounds are caused by vibrations. Higher pitch = faster vibrations (shorter/tighter object). Louder sound = bigger vibrations. Sound travels through solids, liquids, and gases.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils demonstrate that sounds are made by vibrations (e.g. tuning fork in water, rice on drum skin)? Can they identify the pattern between object length/tension and pitch? Can they explain how sound travels from source to ear?
success_criteria: Demonstrate that sound is caused by vibrations
Identify the pattern: shorter/tighter = higher pitch
Explain the relationship between vibration strength and volume
Describe how sound travels from source to ear

vehicles.name: Electrical Circuits
vehicles.description: Enquiry into simple series circuits — building, testing, and troubleshooting. Pupils identify conductors/insulators and explore how voltage affects brightness.
vehicles.variables_independent: number of batteries (voltage) or number of bulbs
vehicles.recording_format: circuit diagrams using symbols -> results table -> conclusion
vehicles.safety_notes: Use only low-voltage cells (1.5V). Never connect directly across battery terminals (short circuit). Do not use mains electricity.
vehicles.expected_outcome: More batteries = brighter bulb. More bulbs in series = dimmer each bulb. Metals conduct; plastic, rubber, wood insulate. Circuits need a complete loop.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils build a working series circuit and draw it using standard symbols? Can they predict and test what happens when components are added? Can they classify materials as conductors or insulators with evidence?
success_criteria: Build a working series circuit with battery, bulb, switch, and wires
Draw the circuit using standard circuit symbols
Predict and test the effect of adding batteries or bulbs
Classify materials as conductors or insulators with evidence

vehicles.name: States of Matter and the Water Cycle
vehicles.description: Observation enquiry exploring solids, liquids, and gases, changes of state, and the water cycle. Includes evaporation rate investigation.
vehicles.variables_independent: location of water sample (sunny windowsill, shaded shelf, cupboard)
vehicles.recording_format: particle diagrams for each state -> evaporation results table -> water cycle diagram with labels
vehicles.safety_notes: Teacher demonstrates boiling water. Pupils do not handle hot water. Thermometers should be non-mercury.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Solids have fixed shape, liquids take container shape, gases fill available space. Heating causes melting/evaporation, cooling causes condensation/freezing. The water cycle is a continuous process.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils describe the properties of solids, liquids, and gases? Can they explain changes of state in terms of heating and cooling? Can they label and explain the water cycle? Can they use their evaporation investigation to explain how temperature affects evaporation rate?
success_criteria: Describe properties of solids, liquids, and gases
Explain melting, freezing, evaporation, and condensation
Draw and label the water cycle accurately
Use investigation results to explain evaporation rate factors

vehicles.name: Light and Shadows
vehicles.description: Investigation into how shadows are formed and how their size changes with distance. Includes exploration of reflection and how we see objects.
vehicles.variables_independent: distance between light source and object
vehicles.recording_format: results table -> line graph -> ray diagram showing light travel
vehicles.safety_notes: Do not shine torches directly into eyes. Supervise mirror use.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Shadows form when opaque objects block light. Shadow size increases as the object moves closer to the light source. Light travels in straight lines. We see objects because light reflects off them into our eyes.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain how shadows are formed using the concept of light travelling in straight lines? Can they predict how shadow size changes with distance? Can they draw a ray diagram showing how we see an object?
success_criteria: Explain that light travels in straight lines
Explain how shadows are formed by opaque objects blocking light
Predict and test how shadow size changes with distance
Draw a ray diagram showing how we see objects (light source -> object -> eye)

vehicles.name: Human Body: Digestion and Teeth
vehicles.description: Research and model-building enquiry exploring the digestive system, types and functions of teeth, and food chains.
vehicles.recording_format: labelled diagram of digestive system -> tooth investigation results -> food chain diagram
vehicles.safety_notes: Egg shell experiment uses cola — no drinking. Hand washing after handling food items.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Pupils can describe the journey of food through the digestive system, name and describe functions of different tooth types, and construct food chains with producers, predators and prey.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils describe the function of each part of the digestive system in sequence? Can they name the types of teeth and explain their functions? Can they construct a food chain using correct terminology (producer, predator, prey)?
success_criteria: Describe the function of each main part of the digestive system
Name the types of human teeth and explain their functions
Construct a food chain with correct use of arrows and terminology
Explain what would happen if one organism in a food chain was removed

vehicles.name: Evolution and Adaptation
vehicles.description: Research enquiry exploring how living things have changed over time — fossils as evidence, variation, adaptation, and natural selection (age-appropriate introduction).
vehicles.recording_format: timeline of life on Earth -> beak adaptation results table -> explanation text
vehicles.safety_notes: No specific hazards. Ensure sensitivity around evolution/creation discussions.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Fossils show how organisms have changed over time. Offspring vary from parents. Organisms are adapted to their environments. Over time, natural selection means better-adapted organisms survive and reproduce.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain how fossils provide evidence for change over time? Can they describe how an organism is adapted to its environment? Can they explain the basic mechanism of natural selection (variation -> selection -> inheritance)?
success_criteria: Explain how fossils provide evidence that living things have changed
Describe how at least 2 organisms are adapted to their environments
Explain that offspring vary and this variation can be inherited
Describe how natural selection leads to evolution over time

vehicles.name: Separating Mixtures
vehicles.description: Practical investigation into dissolving, solutions, and methods of separating mixtures — filtering, sieving, evaporating. Distinguishes reversible from irreversible changes.
vehicles.recording_format: method diagram for each separation -> results table -> reversible vs irreversible sorting activity
vehicles.safety_notes: Wear safety goggles during evaporation. Teacher supervises heating. Do not taste solutions.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Different mixtures require different separation methods based on particle size and solubility. Dissolving and filtering are reversible. Burning and cooking are irreversible.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils choose an appropriate separation method for a given mixture and explain why? Can they explain the difference between dissolving and melting? Can they classify changes as reversible or irreversible with examples?
success_criteria: Choose and explain the correct separation method for different mixtures
Explain what happens when a substance dissolves
Recover a dissolved substance by evaporation
Classify changes as reversible or irreversible with examples
